docs.lead_paragraph: Carolina, who lives on the vertiginous hills of a Caracas slum, says she fell pregnant with her third child last year because birth control pills went scarce.

headline.main: Pregnant Women in Scarcity-Hit Venezuela Battle to Dodge Zika
headline.print_headline: Pregnant Women in Scarcity-Hit Venezuela Battle to Dodge Zika

docs.snippet: Carolina, who lives on the vertiginous hills of a Caracas slum, says she fell pregnant with her third child last year because birth control pills went scarce.

docs.lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee will issue guidelines this week aimed at protecting athletes and visitors from Zika, a mosquito-borne virus spreading rapidly across South America months before the Rio de Janeiro Games in August.

headline.main: IOC to Issue Zika Guidance as Virus Spreads Before Rio Games
headline.print_headline: IOC to Issue Zika Guidance as Virus Spreads Before Rio Games

docs.snippet: The International Olympic Committee will issue guidelines this week aimed at protecting athletes and visitors from Zika, a mosquito-borne virus spreading rapidly across South America months before the Rio de Janeiro Games in August.

docs.lead_paragraph: Donors must help Libya rebuild its devastated health care system and fight increasing outbreaks of disease, not wait for a unity government to be formed, the health minister and the World Health Organisation (WHO) said on Wednesday.

headline.main: Libya's Health Needs Can't Wait for Unity Government, Minister Says
headline.print_headline: Libya's Health Needs Can't Wait for Unity Government, Minister Says

docs.snippet: Donors must help Libya rebuild its devastated health care system and fight increasing outbreaks of disease, not wait for a unity government to be formed, the health minister and the World Health Organisation (WHO) said on Wednesday.

docs.lead_paragraph: Grappling with a mosquito-borne virus linked to brain damage in infants, El Salvador is advising all women in the country not to get pregnant until 2018.

headline.main: El Salvador’s Advice on Zika Virus: Don’t Have Babies
headline.print_headline: El Salvador’s Advice on Zika: Don’t Have Babies

docs.abstract: El Salvador, beset by mosquito-borne Zika virus, advises all women in country to avoid becoming pregnant until 2018; warning is indication of government's desperation over epidemic, which has spread across Latin America and infected more than million people in Brazil.
docs.snippet: Grappling with a mosquito-borne virus linked to brain damage in infants, El Salvador is advising all women in the country not to get pregnant until 2018.

byline.contributor: Gene Palumbo contributed reporting from San Salvador, and Donald G. McNeil Jr. from San Francisco.

docs.lead_paragraph: The evidence is slim, but some experts want scientists to investigate whether a virus linked to birth defects and commonly transmitted by mosquitoes could be spread sexually.

headline.main: Zika Virus: Two Cases Suggest It Could Be Spread Through Sex
headline.print_headline: Two Cases Suggest That Zika Virus Could Be Spread Through Sexual Contact

docs.abstract: Scientists suggest Zika virus, thought to cause infant brain damage and paralysis in adults, may be transmissible through sexual contact, not just mosquitoes; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention call for further study, but say evidence is still too slim to issue formal travel ban.
docs.snippet: The evidence is slim, but some experts want scientists to investigate whether a virus linked to birth defects and commonly transmitted by mosquitoes could be spread sexually.

keywords.value: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Few of the modern complaints about American health care are really new, the historian Nancy Tomes writes in her book.
docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger reviews book Remaking the American Patient: How Madison Avenue and Modern Medicine Turned Patients Into Consumers by Nancy Tomes.
docs.snippet: Few of the modern complaints about American health care are really new, the historian Nancy Tomes writes in her book.

keywords.value: Remaking the American Patient: How Madison Avenue and Modern Medicine Turned Patients into Consumers (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works

docs.lead_paragraph: A rare tropical disease is spreading in parts of Latin America and the Caribbean. The mosquito-borne Zika virus usually causes a mild illness but is now suspected in an unusual birth defect and possibly other health issues. Some things to know:

headline.main: What to Know About the Tropical Zika Virus in Latin America
headline.print_headline: What to Know About the Tropical Zika Virus in Latin America

docs.snippet: A rare tropical disease is spreading in parts of Latin America and the Caribbean. The mosquito-borne Zika virus usually causes a mild illness but is now suspected in an unusual birth defect and possibly other health issues. Some things to know:

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. doctors are fielding a spate of calls from expectant mothers who recently traveled to countries affected by the Zika virus and fear possible exposure to the mosquito-borne infection linked to a spike in fetal brain damage in Brazil.

headline.main: U.S. Moms-To-Be Seek Reassurance About Zika After Trips Abroad
headline.print_headline: U.S. Moms-To-Be Seek Reassurance About Zika After Trips Abroad

docs.snippet: U.S. doctors are fielding a spate of calls from expectant mothers who recently traveled to countries affected by the Zika virus and fear possible exposure to the mosquito-borne infection linked to a spike in fetal brain damage in Brazil.

docs.lead_paragraph: The mosquito-borne Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in thousands of babies in Brazil, is likely to spread to all countries in the Americas except for Canada and Chile, the World Health Organization said on Monday.

headline.main: Zika Virus Set to Spread Across Americas, Spurring Vaccine Hunt
headline.print_headline: Zika Virus Set to Spread Across Americas, Spurring Vaccine Hunt

docs.snippet: The mosquito-borne Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in thousands of babies in Brazil, is likely to spread to all countries in the Americas except for Canada and Chile, the World Health Organization said on Monday.

headline.main: U.S. Moms-To-Be Seek Reassurance About Zika After Trips Abroad
